post.message:
Great article!

I just have one question, why did you need to do the chi-squared test to the day of the week distribution? I don't see how "randomness" can affect the data. If you have the day then you know the week day don't you? Or maybe I'm just missing something :)

You definitely know the weekday if you know the day! :)

The idea with the chi-squared test in this context is actually something different. The idea is to test whether the counts of tweets is distributed randomly among all the days of the week; the chi-squared test is used to evaluate how likely it is that the observed differences between the days arose by chance. When you do something like
table(wday(tweets$timestamp))
you get the number of tweets for each weekday. Doing the chi-squared test on this distribution (which is shown visually in the histogram) compares the measured distribution of counts to some theoretical distribution of counts (perhaps equal frequencies of counts for all days). You get a chi-squared value and you know the number of degrees of freedom (6 in this case, 7 days of the week minus 1), so you can calculate the probability of observing this difference (or a more extreme difference than this).

I hope that clarifies what I was trying to do here! And I am definitely happy to hear feedback if something doesn't make sense or if I have made an error somewhere.

Oh, I see now! Now you know that it's more likely to have a more "random" distribution of your tweeting rather than tweet at the same rate during the week.

Thank you!
This is great. Lovely code and interesting results but the best thing about it is the c("midnightblue", "deepskyblue4", "aquamarine3") colour scheme. So pretty!
Thank you! I do love me a nice color scheme. :)
Great work. Also this color scheme looks amazing.

Just to say nice post and thanks for sharing. It's nice to see all we can do/get from one data table, right?!

Keep blogging like this!
Thank you for the kind words!

For followup: How can you definitively decide the number of clusters or should you? How stable is the solution when you don't set the seed? How do you compare the different classifier algorithms? And finally, how do you interpret the groups to know what original factors (pre PCA) contribute to and distinguish the distinct clusters.

This type of end to end blog takes a lot of work. Thanks! Looking forward to more of this.

Thanks for reading, Alton! According to my rigorous analysis, the definitive number of clusters is 2.5 +/- 0.5. 😜 No, I'm being silly and facetious but that is sort of my take on what has happened here. Do the counties truly have underlying clustering structure in these data? Probably not into cleanly separated clusters a la the iris data set, but in my perspective, there is evidence that we can see similar counties grouping together. The algorithms (Ward hierarchical clustering + k-means clustering) are numerically different so it is not shocking to me that they didn't agree down to <1, given how noisy these data are. If I had to make a call in a situation like this for a business decision maker, I would probably go with 3 clusters; the super duper low population counties are fairly different from the more intermediate population clusters.

I set the seed for the last two plots only so that colors would match for the labels and the points; otherwise the calls to kmeans() in autoplot and geom_label_repel would end up with different numbers assigned to the clusters (same counties together in a cluster, but calling the cluster "1" vs. "2"). I hope I've explained that clearly enough.

And I set the seed before the bootstrap resampling only for reproducibility. If I did more resampling runs, or a different set of runs, the stability for the 3 Ward-hierarchical clusters were always around 0.8, 0.7, 0.7. The more stable cluster is the lowest population cluster.

I didn't do detailed work on which were the most important health care indicators that distinguished between the clusters. Based on what I *did* do, I think the best way to think about that would be to look at PC1, which accounts for the most variability between the clusters. The health care indicators which have the highest coefficients in PC1 would be the ones which account for the most differences between clusters. The top couple are the percent population over 65, the percent who are food insecure, the rate of uninsured children, and the rate of people who couldn't see a doctor due to cost. Most of those sound economic, I guess?

Thanks for thinking about all this and asking questions!
Hi could you kindly explain what is happening in your R code on sentiment analysis for the Bar plot? I'm a bit confused what the first line of code seeks to achieve. Thanks in advance.

Sure! If you notice in the previous code block, the last columns in the "tweets" data frame contain the sentiment scores. The call to colSums() adds up the total score over all tweets for each sentiments. We will get, for example, the total sum over all tweets of ALL the anger sentiment scores, ALL the joy scores, etc. The point of these couple of lines of code in this section is to make a data frame for plotting that has the total score for each sentiment, something like:
sentiment count
anger ~2000
anticipation ~4500
...........

Hi, I have a very basic question. If a data frame contains tweets and posting date for the tweets, do you know if there is an easy way of printing the data frame in the R Markdown code? I haven't been able to find anything related to displaying data frame content, especially when one of the columns contains a long text string, such as the tweet content. Thanks in advance.

It can be tough to actually look at the content of a data frame when one of the columns is such a long text string, right? It prints out over lots of lines and looks messy. I think this is what you are asking about?

Probably the best answer is to just look at one or a few of the columns that you are especially interested in and print those. You can subset the data frame by referring to the columns by number:
tweets[,c(1:3)]
or
tweets[,c(2,4,6)]
Or you can specifically grab the columns by their names
tweets[,'text']

You can subset based on row as well; put any logical expression for the rows before the comma.

In R Markdown, you can increase the width of the code that displays by changing an option. Put
options(width=80)
or however wide you want in a code chunk at the beginning of your R Markdown document, probably with echo = FALSE. You have to be a little careful with that, depending on how you are going to display your document (the web, etc) but it can get you a few more columns sometimes.

Let me know if this isn't what you meant!

Thanks for the info about setting the width and setting the echo option. I've used SAS for years, but am fairly new to R. Given the large number of packages available, I was surprised that I couldn't find anything online related to displaying well formatted data frames in html or pdf documents using knitr. Especially when some of the columns in the data frame would need to wrap to fit on a page. I'm interested in printing the user name, number of retweets, and message content.

I've found the following workaround (which may not be the best way to do it):

#df1 is a data frame containing twitter text, number of retweets, and twitter name of account that posted the original message

library(dplyr)
library(gridExtra)
textForm = sapply(lapply(df1$tweets, strwrap, width=30), paste, collapse="\n")
df2 <-data.frame(textForm)
df3 <- select(df1, -tweets)
df4 <- bind_cols(d2,d3)
grid.table(df4)

The shortcoming is that the grid.table command only displays a portion of the data frame. I'll look at the options to see if the length can be extended in order to display the entire data frame.

thanks for your reply, and great job with your blog!

Ah, if you want to display nicely formatted HTML, you should take a look at kable or maybe xtable. If you are working in R Markdown, you'll need to tell it to print it "as is" since it outputs HTML and you don't want it to interpret it as markdown.

Admittedly, most of the real-life applications I've seen of NLP are not in literature; they are in marketing research, healthcare records, speech recognition/processing, other AI, etc. Although, come to think of it, having a computer understand a plot structure in literature definitely overlaps the AI research. I'm willing to say, on the one hand, that understanding literature at a deeper level is important (are there common plot shapes to more popular stories? across cultures? etc?) for its own sake. On the other hand, an analysis like this one is sort of a tiny beginning of teaching computers what we mean with language/story/plot, which is important for processing text in a lot of different applications.

The sentiment analysis doesn't seem to work well with negations.

get_nrc_sentiment("This is not good news for me") is interpreted as positive! How reliable is this?

This is part of how these sentiment lexicons work; the NRC lexicon is based on unigrams (i.e. single words) so it can't see a whole sentence at a time. I talk a bit more in detail about this in my first blog post on sentiment analysis. I believe the AFINN lexicon has some bigrams in it (things like "not good", etc) and if I am not mistaken, the Stanford CoreNLP tools make some attempt to deal with general negation in sentences. You also have the issue of sarcasm and irony, right? It is a TOUGH problem!

The good thing, though, is that you can usually get a rough idea of the sentiment of a chunk of text without worrying too much about these things, especially in narrative form like a novel. Sometimes you will get it wrong (like in your example) but most of the time you will get it right. Narrative certainly includes negation and sarcasm/irony, but not often in extended sections for most styles of literature. You are absolutely right that this is a limitation of this approach.

tweets$timestamp <- ymd_hms(tweets$timestamp)

It sounds like your dates are in a different format, so you'll need to use a different function from lubridate. Hmmm, I would recommend using the lubridate package to deal with dates vs. as.POSIX or anything like that; I have found it to make dealing with dates much easier and more pleasant. Here is an introduction on how to use it. You'll need to do a bit of string handling first for your original character strings, but then you will pass the strings to a lubridate function (maybe ymd_hms after you wrangle your strings?) and you will get date type objects out of the function. Then you will be able to analyze and plot using the date objects.

Excellent post!
Two minor comments and a recent Supreme Court ruling.
1. Voter turnout -- academics, lawyers and international journalists look at "voter turnout" as percent of eligible population,
but political hacks, look at it as percent of registered voters. Most states publish voter registration statistics by precinct, but not Utah or at least not since 2014! Statewide voter registration by party is available here:
https://elections.utah.gov/...

The complete voter file, where one could compile one's own statistics (with R crosstabs); costs over $1,000!!!
and is available here:
https://elections.utah.gov/...

2. Voter turnout formula and percentages in general -- when calculating percentages, I usually put the fraction in parenthesis and then show multiplication by 100 just to make the order of operations unambiguous.
So, instead of this formula:
turnout = votes/VAP*100

I tend to write:
turnout = (votes/VAP)*100

in order to make clear to the human reader that I do NOT mean:

turnout = votes/(VAP*100)

Its a stylistic leftover from when some calculators or programming languages used left to right evaluation.

Supreme Court ruling
The US Supreme Court ruled this week in a Texas redistricting case Evenwel v. Abbott favoring the US Census 10 year census total population over using US Census American Community Survey estimates of Citizen Voting Age Population (CVAP).
SCOTUSblog coverage of Evenwel v. Abbot here:
http://www.scotusblog.com/c...

and the US Supreme Court opinion here:
http://www.supremecourt.gov...

I found this note about the $1,000 voter file amusing (ROFL).
"Utah law requires that statewide voter registration data be available to the public. Utah statute has established a fee of $1,050.00 to acquire the voter database. The file is in tab-deliminted format and includes the following fields:...NOTE: the file is very large (150 MB). The database requires one business day to generate. Please be aware that because the Utah Voter Database is updated in real-time, it is constantly changing. The fee is for a one-time acquisition of the Database; updates are not provided. Each subsequent request for the file will require a new payment."

Utah only has 1.5 million voters; with modern computers and databases it does not take "one business day" to generate 1.5 million records. The office may require "one business day's" NOTICE so they can run a job after the day's transactions have been applied. Once the query is written, the dump of the database should be a straightforward task.a

I work with Florida voter data and Florida has 12 million voters.
http://dos.myflorida.com/el...

With a notebook computer that has an Intel i5 processor, I can load 12 million records in less than 2 hours. So, I can't see why a dump of a query would take "one business day to generate."
But the file is VERY LARGE!!!!!!!!! For goodness sake...

You can also test on Mac OS X on travis and on multiple releases, just add this to the beginning of your travis.yml file:

```
os:
- linux
- osx

r:
- release
- oldrelease
- devel
```

Hi Julia:

Pretty interesting work, you've inspired me to pursue some ideas I've had around this exact subject :)

I was wondering--what heuristic did you use to choose the filter parameter? You're really probing the story structure here, so the cutoff sets a "time" scale (in the reader's timeline) and determines the size of the feature. 3 feels right--you're looking for 3-5 big swings in the book. I wonder if there's a secret author's rule of thumb that would verify that this is the right number.

You're exactly right; if we use a different parameter for the low pass filter, we will get either more, higher frequency features or fewer features (even perhaps just one big simple shape). I tried a few different values to see what made the most sense, and in that sense I suppose it is rather like k-means clustering. The resulting shapes were pretty robust to choices around 3 or 4 components. Keeping only 2 components didn't show much structure, and going up to 6 or more resulted in a shape that didn't really show an overarching plot structure in a typical sense (although they did do a good job of matching the shapes of the raw sentiment as shown in the plots here).

Hi Julia,
Thanks for the tutorial, it's very nice and helpful!
However, I have a question: how do you know which word in a sentence has which entry in the sentiment analysis (using get_nrc_sentiment)? Is there a way to see the individual scores of each word?
Also, is there a way to find, for example, the most positive/negative tweet from a big tweet data frame?
Thanks!

Best,
Johnn

If you want to look at the sentiment for each word, you should check out the unnest_tokens function in the tidytext package that I have written with Dave Robinson; you can use that to get the individual sentiment score for each word. That can lead to finding the most positive/negative tweet without too much additional trouble. Check out the README and vignettes for the tidytext package; I think that will set you on your way pretty well.

Ah, OK... For this blog post, I interactively/manually tried out all the words in the line:
get_nrc_sentiment("O")
get_nrc_sentiment("holy")
get_nrc_sentiment("night") etc
to find out what the sentiment for each word was. This was a great way to get a feel for how the algorithm works and how the various words are scored (and for writing a blog post) but it isn't a great approach for a bigger project, obviously. For that, you would want to use something like unnest_tokens from tidytext.

The UTF-8 issue you mention persists, but can be easily solved with "iconv":

austen_books() %>%
mutate(text = iconv(text, to = 'latin1')) %>%
group_by(book) %>%
unnest_tokens(sentence, text, token = 'sentences') %>%
ungroup() %>%
filter(row_number() == 39) %>%
select(sentence)

Julia, I liked the slides. My wife is a tenured academic & very career-driven -- but she is considering changing to be a part-time SAHM to homeschool our kids. Although I fully support any decision she makes & personally like the idea of homeschooling, I do worry about her feeling of professional fulfillment while she's dedicating time to educate our kids. Can you shed some light on how long you were at home w/ your kids, what the transition back to working was like, & how you reentered the job world?

Sure! These are all super personal decisions, and I don't know how much one person's experience or preference can extend to someone else? But... I was home full-time for about 4 years, from when my second child was born until my third child was about a year old. I don't regret it at all; it was the right choice for me as an individual, given where I was personally at the time and what I wanted from my life right then, and it was the right choice for us as a family. I transitioned back to paid work when my youngest was out of that baby stage, and I got that first job back because of networking and personal connections. I don't think I could have gotten an academic job again, after time away, but there have been a lot of opportunities for me outside of academia that use the skills I developed as a researcher/astronomer/etc.

I guess the biggest takeaways for me, from those years, are that I value them and I am not sorry at all I did it. Eventually, it was the right time for me to transition back to paid work, and I am happy doing what I'm doing now too; I am obviously not particularly interested if someone wants to have some kind of SAHM/working-mom fight. 😉 When I left paid work, I did literally think to myself, "Gosh, is anyone ever going to hire me ever again?!" but someone did. (I was hired to that first job back a) by someone who knew me from grad school and b) first as a contractor and before being hired full-time.)

I hope that is helpful; I know these are complicated, personal choices.

I've been trying to get the code to work for a while and can't figure out what I'm doing wrong. I believe the issue is using the "coord_proj(us_laea_proj). I keep getting the following error, "Error: CoordProj was built with an incompatible version of ggproto.
Please reinstall the package that provides this extension." Is this due to the ggplot2 upgrade? Thanks for your excellent posts!
after some more reading, i replaced "coord_proj(us_laea_proj)" with coord_map("polyconic") and it seems to do the trick.

I believe one big issue here is, as you mention, the new release of ggplot2. When you see any errors about "incompatible version of ggproto", what you need to do is make sure ggplot2 is installed fresh, the re-install the other packages you want to use (in this case ggalt). Use force = TRUE if you need to.

Unfortunately, in this case, the OTHER big issue is there is apparently a bug in coord_proj() from ggalt so that it doesn't play nicely with the new version of ggplot2: https://github.com/hrbrmstr...

We'll have to wait and/or help Bob fix this, I guess!

You can definitely do some tokenizing by paragraph using the tidytext package:
https://cran.r-project.org/...
Or the underlying implementation of tokenizing from tokenizers:
https://cran.r-project.org/...
The reason that lines can be helpful is that they contain about equal amounts of text, while paragraphs can vary in length much more. It depends on the kind of question you are asking!

Hi, interesting post, thanks. I do wonder about the cone shape in the scatter plot. It suggests at least two possible interpretations: 1) the most popular tags are just always popular (real effect that changes both tag count and weekend/day interest), or 2) that the lower tag counts "cause" the apparent weekend/weekday differences because of lower group sizes. The group sizes range over 2 orders of magnitude!

I'm curious if there are good ways to separate out these two possibilities, or if you think I'm worried over nothing.

That's a great observation! I tend to think it is your option #2 because these tags have been filtered to only those with > 20,000 questions; these are not tags with only a smattering of questions asked about them. I did not run a statistical test to get confidence intervals on the proportions here, but that would be the way to do it! You can find the code that I used here, and would go from there with... prop.test maybe?
https://www.kaggle.com/juli...

In the errors, it looks like you just aren't matching your parentheses; you are throwing in an extra ) or missing an ( or something like that.

return a data frame of two integers and an n and not two words

<int> <int> <dbl>

Is that yellow area in the middle of your Utah county map one county with about 1,000,000 people or is it ten counties giving a total population of 10,000,000 people, or 100 counties with 100,000,000 people? This kind of map really needs the county boundaries drawn in, otherwise its meaningless to someone who doesn't know the counties. Setting a colour in the `stroke` parameter should do it. Maps of population *density* don't need the boundaries as much. See the definition of Intrinsic and Extrinsic properties: https://en.wikipedia.org/wi... and read Ken Field's Cartoblog for more great tips!

Sure, good points. I recently read some dataviz research about how much trouble people have interpreting choropleth mappings of counts (vs. rates or densities) AT ALL, so depending on one's audience, such a map may be an iffy idea altogether.

I am currently working on text mining to get sentiment score using the AFINN lexicon. I have some questions regarding your book chapter 4 and 9: N-grams. I am trying to get scores using the negate_words <- c("not", "without", "no", "can't", "don't", "won't"). However, I am still confused how to get scores because you only focus the paring words. Namely, I would like to get if a sentence involves negating words, the point should be -1*score.

Could you please share me an example of the code to get the scores? It would be very appreciated if you give me some comments.

You can use that approach of using the negation words to see which words are contributing in the wrong direction a lot, but with unigram/"bag of word" sentiment analysis, you can't really just change the sign of the whole sentence. The idea here is to figure out which words are being used with negation words in your text so you can get a handle of how wrong your sentiment analysis might be. You could then use n-gram analysis to find out how often some word *is* used with a negation word to decide if you need to throw it out or treat it differently.

Say you found out that "like" was contributing a lot to sentiment in your text but was often following a negating word. You could then count up all the bigrams with "like" in the second position and see what proportion had a negating word in the first position. If it is a proportion that is too high for your purposes, you could decide that "like" is not an OK word for positive sentiment for your text; it's actually often used in negative ways. You'll have to use other words to determine the sentiment of your text.

Appreciate your reply! However, how can we apply your answer to get a new score incorporating negating words? For example, if 'I like you = 1', then I wanna calculate as followed: 'I don't like you = -1' by automatically. I am trying to fix the code but still stuck in...

That's not quite how sentiment analysis using lexicons like these works, actually. It looks at a piece of text and adds up the sentiment scores of all the individual words. For many kinds of text, from literature to social media to, say, Yelp reviews, it can work well overall in a statistical sense. For example, check this out from my collaborator Dave:
http://varianceexplained.or...
It is not able to get at the kind of measurement you are talking about here, though. At least not in examples I have seen!

Thank you Julia. Then could you please let me know how does sentiment score come out? For example, Sentiment = (P − N) / Count of all words. Each review in Dave's example has own their sentiment score.
You can try some different approaches and see what works best. In Dave's post, he took the approach of using a mean sentiment score for each review, i.e. sentiment = mean(afinn_score).

Hi Julia,
Just looking for some rough guidance/insights here to save me a few hours of searching, cause I've already had a look around and couldn't see a clear answer.

The timestamp that gets pulled in with "searchTwitter()" is UTC? But it doesn't convert based on the users timezone? As in to say, someone could tweet at 11:00pm their time while someone else on the other side of the world tweets straight after at 9:01am their time, but both are recorded as 3:00pm and 3:01pm UTC?
Location data seems, from my testing, to be missing from 90%+ of tweets? There is no way to modify that, even if it is at a broader geographical region? I've seen the USA soda vs pop type plots, but I'm not sure whether they were done by dropping the 90% with missing GPS data, or before other geographic data were removed from the API etc?
The point of all this, it's near impossible to get tweets from a specific region and accurately plot them against true time of day?

Feel free to point me to other resources. When I google "R twitter analysis" there aren't too many results returned.
Thanks so much

The timestamp is UTC; that is right. You can use your knowledge about who sent a tweet to assign a timezone to it, like I did here for my own tweets:
https://juliasilge.com/blog...

When a user sends a tweet, the user herself decides whether the tweet is geocoded. For example, I don't have geocoding set on my own tweets because it creeps me out a bit; there are no locations set on most of my own tweets (unless I'm on vacation at a famous place or something). The analyses you've seen based on geocoded Twitter data use only tweets that *have* been geocoded by their users, like this dataset:
https://sites.google.com/si...

Fascinating! One thing that jumps out on that Austen list: about a third of the male words are present tense, whereas none of the female words are. I would guess (and a quick search through P&P seems to back this up) that the present tense words are within reported speech rather than author narration. (So, characters talking about men vs. the narrator doing so.) You don't see the same split in Eliot (in any case Eliot as a narrator speaks in present tense more often than Austen, I would guess, so the reported speech link might be less clear cut).

I'm glad you are using this approach! Each question is a document here, so to connect documents to topics, you want the gamma probabilities. You can take the output of tidy(your_lda_object, matrix = "gamma") and find the document YOU are interested in, using filter. Then use arrange to sort by gamma. If the topic model has done a good job of modeling the documents into topics, there will be some topics with very high probabilities and other with probabilities close to zero.
Thanks! That helped a lot, and I really appreciate you taking the time to respond.

I had the same problem. In my case it had to do with the "reshape" package. After installation, the tidy() command did not work on my LDA-output anymore. Not loading the reshape package in the next session solved the problem, however, I am wondering why the error occurs?

Do you mean reshape2? There must be some kind of namespace conflict. I'm looking at the exported namespace for reshape2 here:
https://github.com/hadley/r...
Nothing is jumping out at me immediately. Hmmmm...

I had also installed reshape2, but my problem occurred with reshape.
To check it, I loaded reshape, ran LDA, used tidy() to LDA-output: 'Error in mutate_impl(.data, dots) : binding not found: 'Var1'.'
I opened R again, did NOT load reshape, ran LDA, applied tidy(): Worked perfectly.
When I did the same procedure with loading reshape2, it worked perfectly as well.

Yep, definitely some kind of namespace conflict. Depending on which package you are using more functions from, you can NOT load the package using `library(reshape)`, but instead use the function like `reshape::super_great_function(arguments)`.
Great, thanks!

chapter = cumsum(str_detect(text, regex("^chapter [\\divxlc]
What does square bracketed code signify here? It gives same output without it. Can someone help me interpret its significance?

The characters within the brackets are a regex pattern to look for the Roman numerals that say what the chapters are, like "Chapter XXVII" for the 27th chapter. I expect that the output is not actually the same without it? If you don't use that, it will break at any use of the word chapter in the novels, not just the chapter headings that have "chapter" and then some Roman numerals after it.

One easy byproduct of the above 'skip-gramming' method is that one can build TCMs (term co-occurrence matrices) that measure term co-occurrences within a local context window. Closer 2 tokens are, higher their TCM value.

And all this would need is that the pairwise_count() fnc be used not on skipgramID as at present, but on a row_number() ID column. That way, closer 2 tokens are in a local context, higher their pairwise_count().

I've been trying to apply your tutorial to my own data, and I ran into problems with the step:

pmi_svd <- irlba(pmi_matrix, 256, maxit = 1e3)

Thanks to Google and Github (https://github.com/bwlewis/... I discovered this is due to having NA's in my matrix. On Github someone posited the idea this may be due to diacritics. So I went on a crusade, learned some stuff and found out my string data is already in either unknown encoding, or in UTF-8 (the ones with diacritics).

I've pinpointed the problem to where I'm going from unigram_probs to tidy_skipgrams. In unigram_probs. I still have the word "financiële" (meaning "financial"). In tidy_skipgrams this has become "financiã«le". It makes it's introduction already at the first line:
tidy_skipgrams <- data_long %>%
unnest_tokens(ngram, antwoord, token = "ngrams", n = 8)

So apparently using ngrams rather than single words introduces this. "financiã«le" also occurs with bigrams.

I can do (at least) two things things: Replace all diacritics with their non-diacritic
equivalent (no problem for Dutch), or set all NA's from the pmi_matrix to zero.

So for me, this problem turns out to have a work-around. I wanted to share this here, though, in case others run into the same problem. Julia, you wrote the tidytext package, right? Is there a step underneath the hood that leads to this problem?

Kind regards,
Jolien ten Velden

What I found weird is that for unigrams everything works fine, but for bigrams it doesn't.

The one-line solution for me, though, was
data$text <- iconv(data$text, from="UTF-8", to="ASCII//TRANSLIT")

Hope it can be helpful for others with the same problem. :)

Your one-line solution is a nice fix. The conversion to ASCII//TRANSLIT eliminates accents and other special characters and returns their ascii "equivalent". I would probably use this, or at least test the effect of this, in most cases.

To see the effect in windows (with 1252 encoding):

I talk about it a little bit at the end of the previous post:
https://juliasilge.com/blog...
PMI stands for "pointwise mutual information", and it's the log of the probability of finding two words together, normalized for the probability of finding each of the words alone. Basically, it gets at which words are associated with each other in the collection of text.

Hmmm, if I am understanding your question here, you *do* need to get your data to a tidy form before doing pairwise operations. If your data is still untidy (i.e. lots of text in each row vs a single word or a bigram or the observational unit you are interested in) then pairwise_count() will try to count up how many times each WHOLE ROW is used together, I think? I could easily be mistaken, but I think that using SVD on the co-occurrence matrix makes this approach more similar to LSA ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wi... ) than Word2Vec.

The difference between LSA and W2V (and I think the reason you're getting funky stuff as the top-value when doing the vector arithmetic) is that LSA doesn't guarantee a smooth latent space. I believe Word2Vec does. That's the trade-off. You can get things that map to similar latent spaces in LSA so prediction and indexing are easier, but going the other direction doesn't necessarily work as well as W2V. That's I think a big part of the reason that deep learning researchers use Word2Vec for the latent space instead of LSI.**

But maybe I'm completely off base here. It would be worth checking the reprojection error of all three approaches.

** Actually, LSI/LSA/PCM might all make for continuous latent spaces. I don't have any proof that they don't, but it doesn't seem like it to me.

So I think you can test your word vectors on https://github.com/nicholas... to get a baseline against word2vec, GLoVe etc. Obviously you have to train it on the same text data - most often used

Hi Julia,
Thanks for the awesome tidytext package and for this nice example!

I've applied your code in an analysis of word frequencies in Shakespeare's tragedies, but get inconsistent ordering of words in some of the plays depending on the number of words I choose to plot.
The same thing occurred when I tried reproducing your Jane Austen analysis, e.g. with top_n(30).
Do you know what's going on here?

--UPDATE!--

I found a solution to the ordering issue using some of Debbie Liske's code from a nice datacamp tutorial: https://www.datacamp.com/co...

example:
playWords = playWords %>%
mutate(word = reorder(word, tf_idf)) %>%
group_by(play) %>%
top_n(15,tf_idf) %>%
ungroup() %>%
arrange(play, tf_idf) %>%
mutate(row = row_number())

playWords %>%
ggplot(aes(row, tf_idf, fill = play)) +
geom_col(show.legend = FALSE) +
labs(y = "tf-idf") +
facet_wrap(~play, ncol = 2, scales = "free") +
scale_x_continuous(
breaks = playWords$row,
labels = playWords$word) +
coord_flip()
---

all the best
Peer

This is a great question because PCA and k-means clustering are actually deeply related to each other: https://stats.stackexchange...

But on the other hand, that plot doesn't mean that there are only two clusters. We would need to walk through k-means itself to find an appropriate number of clusters. I like the example in the broom documentation for understanding k-means: https://cran.r-project.org/...

For more general understanding and interpretation of that projection plot (projection of the PC space down to 2 dimensions), try watching that talk from rstudio::conf or this one I did here in SLC: https://www.meetup.com/Salt...

"Mobile developers are located high above the line in this plot, meaning
they feel like they belong at Stack Overflow at high rates compared to
how often they participate. That’s good news for this group!"

Maybe, but the first thing that came to my mind when I saw this was, "If they feel like they belong so much, why aren't they participating more?" I'm not sure which way the causality works here.

Also, it makes perfect sense to me that academic researchers would not feel like they are part of the Stack Overflow community. They are not, by and large, engaged day in and day out in making software used in the "real world". Their work is more...academic. And, while it makes sense that they would want to use SO to see what is going on in industry, to keep their research well-grounded in reality, they may feel they are not part of that community because they aren't. They are part of a different, somewhat related community, called academia. "Not part of this community" doesn't seem to mean, "negative feelings about how I'm treated" (although of course it could). It could also just mean, "I have a different type of job than these people, and this website is mostly about getting work done".

Similar logic would apply to devops, who are a related but different community than programmers on SO (which is part of why they have their own Stack Exchange site, Server Fault).

Thank you very much Julia. I've been playing around with text mining of my own novels - just for fun. Could you point me to any literature that would help classify a sentence like this as having positive sentiment?

Dear Dr. Julia Silge,
Good day.
I accidentally stumbled on this blog post and I think there are some factual and technical errors in it. (Disclaimer: the following comments are solely based on the code snippets and the data analysis conducted in this post).

For instance in the section, "Some high dimensional data":
a) "Principal Component Analysis will transform this high dimensional .. to a new special high dimensional ..special characterstics", is incorrect.
PCA works by determining a set of uncorrelated predictors or variables that explain as much variance as possible. The fundamental concept is to "reduce" the "high dimensional space" to a "lower dimensional space". Therefore, there is "no transformation" involved.

b) The code snippet, `tag_percents` is not clear. For instance, summarising the `Value` by `mean` is dangerous. Suggest median should have been an approporiate choice.

In section "Implementing PCA"
c) In the first paragraph, "...preparing for a machine learning algorithm like PCA", I differ. PCA is an unsupervised dimensionality reduction algorithm best suited at the data preprocessing stage. It is not a "machine learning algorithm", as suggested.
d) The code snippet, `sparse_tag_matrix` has 3 columns `User`,`Tag`,`Value`. From the `tag_percents` variable, it can be generalised `Tag` is a factor variable.
e) The code snippet, `tags_scaled` is unclear too. Are you scaling the `Value` variable? if yes, then why? This variable already contains the mean values so what is the need for scaling?
f) PCA works only for continuous variable, so I'm skeptical how the variable `tags_pca` was obtained?
g) Again in the same code snippet, `tags_pca` how did you determine the value for `n` as `64`? Was it a random choice?

Please advise.
Thank you.

That is a pretty challenging sentence to classify, even for human classifiers (I can see plenty of actual human folks disagreeing with whether that is a positive sentence or not), so I don't know that you are going to find ML classifiers that classify that as positive. The reason why is that ML classifiers use the content of the sentences, and that sentence is full of very negative words.

That being said, two sentiment classifiers that you might check out are the ones in sentimentr:
https://github.com/trinker/...
And the sentiment classifiers in cleanNLP:
https://github.com/statsmat...

Hello there, Ashish! Thanks so much for reading. It seems we have some differences about how to explain or talk about PCA, and ML in general; these kinds of differences are not matters of being "incorrect", though. Principal component analysis is not only useful for dimensionality reduction, and it is called a "machine learning algorithm" in plenty of contexts by plenty of people.

Some of the further thoughts you have here show that you haven't quite followed along. The `sparse_tag_matrix` is of dimension `User` (hundreds of thousands) by dimension `Tag` (hundreds). `Tag` is not a factor variable, and we do need to scale and center the matrix. If we don't, PCA has to account for which tags are just used most overall. The percent of each user's traffic that goes to each tag is indeed a continuous variable.

For PCA using a sparse implementation like that in the irlba package, we must specify how many components to fit out to, so we need to think about how many we are going to use/need. In this analysis, there are meaningful combinations of tags out to components ~20 or so, so fitting to ~64 components gives us plenty of breathing room in that component space. We have ~500 tags so we could fit out to that many components.
Thank you for putting together a really nice presentation! Could you let me know if you have ways to perform reasonableness checks on the beta and gamma code? Many thanks!

Hello Julia,

Thanks so much for the response.

Let's fine tune this discussion from a scientific perspective! Such that (potential) readers of this blog (including myself) might benefit from it.

Principal Components (PC) was first introduced by Karl Pearson in 1901 and improved upon by Hotelling in 1933. The central idea was to reduce the dimensionality of the data set in which there were a large number of interrelated variables while retaining as much variation as possible. C.R. Rao [1] has discussed in how principal components provide a reduction of the data without much loss of information sought from the data. The researchers Abdi and Williams [2] suggest PCA is a multivariate data dimensionality reduction technique in which observations are described by inter-correlated quantitative dependent variables. A detailed treatment of PCA is covered in this book by Jolliffe [3] where its detailed PCA to be a dimensionality reduction method. I would love to see research article’s where PCA is discussed and termed as a machine learning algorithm.

Why scale the values in `tags_scaled` when it already contains the mean values? Besides, as I earlier mentioned, median is a better choice over mean.

So the choice of n for `tags_pca` was indeed a random choice! If so, then I can argue the number could be greater or less than 64. My point here is the absence of a comprehensive statistical rigor. There have been several advancements in science to determine the number of PCs like the Bartlett’s Chi-square test [4], Cattell’s Scree test [5], Velicer’s MAP [6], Horn’s parallel analysis test, Kaiser’s Eigen value greater than unity rule and cross validation [7].

[1]C. R. Rao, "The use and interpretation of principal component analysis in applied research," Sankhyā: The Indian Journal of Statistics, Series A, pp. 329-358, 1964.
[2]H. Abdi and L. J. Williams, "Principal component analysis," Wiley interdisciplinary reviews: computational statistics, vol. 2, pp. 433-459, 2010.
[3]I. Jolliffe, "Principal component analysis," in International encyclopedia of statistical science, ed: Springer, 2011, pp. 1094-1096.
[4]M. S. Bartlett, "Properties of sufficiency and statistical tests," Proc. R. Soc. Lond. A, vol. 160, pp. 268-282, 1937.
[5]R. B. Cattell, "The scree test for the number of factors," Multivariate behavioral research, vol. 1, pp. 245-276, 1966.
[6]W. F. Velicer, "Determining the number of components from the matrix of partial correlations," Psychometrika, vol. 41, pp. 321-327, 1976.
[7]S. Wold, "Cross-validatory estimation of the number of components in factor and principal components models," Technometrics, vol. 20, pp. 397-405, 1978.

So, help me with interpretation. The top few topics seem to have, based on the top 7 terms, no particular "topic" in the ordinary sense. Does this mean we should have excluded more common words from the analysis? Or is it the case that these "topics" are actually a miscellaneous category of "conversations on no particular topic"?

Those first topics involve words that users are putting together and using in semantically similarly ways, like can/can't, want/find/see, and like/good/well/really. Those are related sets of words in terms of how people build sentences and have discussions. They are *not* however about a "topic" in the sense of "what topic are we discussing on Hacker News today". If you wanted to build a model that did not have those words, you could try removing more stop words, like you mention, (but of course you would want to check what is meaningful that you might be removing) or alternatively maybe doing part-of-speech tagging or entity extraction before the topic modeling and only modeling the, say, nouns and words that function similarly in sentences.

I think this depends on what your analytical purpose is, i.e. why you are using topic modeling to start with. Do you want to do inference with these topics? Is it an unsupervised tool for EDA in the text of interest? The approach for choosing a number of topics is an art, not a science; the literature on this is clear that there is not one correct `k` for any given corpus.

Have you taken a look at the detailed documentation for the syuzhet package lately?
https://cran.r-project.org/...

It looks like the author has largely deprecated the function that I use in this blog post, has changed some of its behavior, and doesn't recommend using it anymore. I haven't stayed up to date on the new developments in that package, but you might try out some of the newer approaches such as get_dct_transform().

Thanks for your response. I want to use topic modeling for the explanatory way (EDA). The alternative, human coding is restrictive, and I would like to find a meaningful pattern which is beyond my repertoire. As you said, making decision about the number of k is not at all quantitative, it includes theoretical and contextual evaluation. Since many published studies name all topics that they find, I wonder if this is necessary? Do you know any published work which focuses on specific topics rather than whole? /Best

If I'm correctly understanding the approach you are taking here, I don't think it's useful or necessary for you to "force" all topics to have some meaning, but instead you can use the topics that *are* meaningful to understand your documents.

A workaround for check() was to exclude the file from DESCRIPTION, including it to build ignore, but leaving it in the package itself. The same roughly applies for other files like cran-somments, cran-release and so on. Travis does not like these and may fail, but both are necesarry fur submitting a package. The problem occassionally shows up and than vanishes again. There seems to be changes in the configuration of Travis from time to time.

warnings_are_errors: false

Hi Julia, enjoyed your blog, references and I plan to reproduce your results. A common problem in cybersecurity is fraudsters creating "look-alike-domains" to send emails that fool a company into transferring money. Any thoughts on the best modeling approach to predict look-alike-domains based upon original domains?
Ah, this is not an area I have worked in much but I recently saw this post from the folks at Jumping Rivers about URL hijacking: https://www.jumpingrivers.c...

I talk a little bit about those clusters in my rstudio::conf talk, which is linked at the top of the post. In this particular case, the top cluster is folks who use C# and the Microsoft web stack a lot (almost exclusively) and the bottom, stretched out cluster is folks who don't, on one end front end web dev and on the other end Python and low level tags. I have found using interactive data visualization helpful in interpreting projected data like this, such as a Shiny app that lets you change the axes, like one I show in my talk.

As far as shooting for components that are uncorrelated, that might be nice in an ideal situation and/or if you are going to use these components as predictors in an ML model, but in my experience, they just aren't uncorrelated in real life. In this case, I was looking at how these tags are all related, so kind of a different goal.

Thanks for the insightful post Julia (as usual)!

I reran the modeling part using the new #parsnip package, but got very different results surprisingly, even though penalty and mixture values were set similar to cv.glmnet (i.e., penalty = lambda.1se, mixture = 0 for LASSO).

On a side note, your analysis also provided me with a good example to test out D. Vaughan's awesome #probably package (https://cran.rstudio.com/we....

Appreciate your blogs :)

library(tidyverse)
library(tidymodels)
library(textrecipes)
library(gutenbergr)

# Silge 2018 Text Classification with Tidy Data Principles
# I wondered what can you do with recipes and parsnip?
# One thing I couldn't do was a step for unnest tokens.
# For what it's worth, following Emil Hvitfeldt 2018,
# the same data set and research question as Julia, but using
# recipes and parsnip.

# References:
# https://cran.r-project.org/...
# https://www.tidyverse.org/a...
# https://www.tidyverse.org/a...
# https://cran.r-project.org/...
# https://tidymodels.github.i...
# https://juliasilge.com/blog...

titles <- c("Pride and Prejudice",
"The War of the Worlds")
books <- gutenberg_works(title %in% titles) %>%
gutenberg_download(meta_fields = "title") %>%
select(text, title)

split <- books %>%
initial_split(props = 7 / 10)
books_train <- training(split)
books_test <- testing(split)

books_rec <- recipe(title ~ ., data = books_train) %>%
step_tokenize(text) %>%
step_stopwords(text) %>%
step_tokenfilter(text, max_tokens = 500) %>%
step_tfidf(text) %>%
prep(training = books_train)

train_data <- juice(books_rec)
test_data <- bake(books_rec, books_test, all_predictors())

book_fit <- logistic_reg(mode = "classification") %>%
set_engine("glm") %>%
fit(title ~ ., data = train_data)

pattern <- "(?<=tfidf_text_)(.*)"
coeff <- book_fit %>% pluck("fit", "coefficients") %>%
tibble(rownames = names(.)) %>%
rename(value = ".", param = rownames) %>%
mutate(param = str_extract(string = param, pattern = pattern)) %>%
dplyr::filter(!is.na(param))

p <- coeff %>%
group_by(value > 0) %>%
top_n(10, abs(value)) %>%
ungroup() %>%
ggplot(aes(fct_reorder(param, value), value, fill = value > 0)) +
geom_col(alpha = 0.8, show.legend = FALSE) +
coord_flip() +
labs(x = NULL,
title = "Coefficients that increase/decrease probability the most",
subtitle = "A document mentioning Martians is unlikely to be written by Jane Austen")
p

Hi Julia, thanks for a great introduction to the topic! I have another, a bit more general question - what can we further do with that? Would you use STMs for supervised learning domains as predictive models?

That's a great question. It's important to remember that topic modeling is an unsupervised machine learning algorithm, so it can deal with questions similar to what other unsupervised machine learning approaches can. In the real world, I've used it when I have, say, a lot of text from customers and I need to understand what the content of the text is and at what proportions we see those different kinds of content.

Hello Julia

This is a great tutorial, very practical and easy to apply.
Would be appropriate to apply topic modeling on analyzing focus group discussion transcript? I have a focus group discussion data set. In a focus group, there are six sections which leaded by six probe questions (each section has a question, moderator asked the question then participants discussed or responded the question, some times interacted with moderator or interacted each other ). I am confused if I should treat each section as a document, or treat each time of speaking from each participant as a document?

Thank you

It absolutely is appropriate to use topic modeling for focus group transcripts! I think how you define your "document" depends on your analytical question. From your description, it sounds like I would expect for each section to be a document.

Thank you very much for such quick reply.
I tried treating each section as the document, thus we only have six documents. Does this mean that the number of topics should be very small? maybe no larger than 6?

And I tried use
eval_heldout = map(topic_model1, eval.heldout, heldout$missing)

to get the heldout to help estimate the number of topic, however, the result came out like this:

Error in mutate_impl(.data, dots) : Evaluation error: subscript out of bounds.

What does mean "out of bounds"?

Thank you

Oh no, I'd try each section per focus group as a document, so you have 6 * the number of focus groups for the number of documents. I don't think this algorithm could function well with just six documents.

As far as how many topics to try, check out the documentation for stm(): "For short corpora focused on very specific subject matter (such as survey experiments) 3-10 topics is a useful starting range. For small corpora (a few hundred to a few thousand) 5-50 topics is a good place to start. Beyond these rough guidelines it is application specific. Previous applications in political science with medium sized corpora (10k to 100k documents) have found 60-100 topics to work well. For larger corpora 100 topics is a useful default size. Of course, your mileage may vary."
Thank you Juila, your suggestion is super helpful!!

bound = map_dbl(topic_model1, function(x) max(x$convergence$bound)),
lfact = map_dbl(topic_model1, function(x) lfactorial(x$settings$dim$K)),

iterations = map_dbl(topic_model1, function(x) length(x$convergence$bound)))

k_result
k_result %>%

Hello Julia,

I read stm R package for structure topic modeling, as noted, positive correlation indicates the two topics tend to appear in one document. However how we interpret negative correlation?
What is difference between topic prevalence and expected topic proportion? Assuming we want to find which topic is the most popular topic, mentioned most frequently by people in the data corpus, should we use topic prevalence or expected topic proportion?
I appreciate your help.

Dan

When topics are negatively correlated, it's like any other negative correlation; having one topic means you tend to NOT see the other topic within the same document.

Expected topic proportion and topic prevalence mean the same thing! Just synonyms. 😄

Great post, thank you. I have a question regarding model classification. In this example, the model is able to classify 4005 observations of the total of 4876 observations in the test data set. How should one deal with the remaining 871 observations? In my data set , using this model only ends up with about 30% of the observations in the test data set being classified.

I haven't re-run this tonight, but if I'm remembering correctly, the observations excluded here are made entirely of words that did not make it into the model: stop words and words used fewer than 10 times. Take a look at what is in your testing dataset and what's in your tidy dataset of words, and see what decisions led to so few observations being kept around.

Thanks for the response. It looks like in my particular situation, there are only 20 coefficients left in my final model, which is likely why only 30% of my test data can be classified.
If I remove the line: filter(lambda == model$lambda.1se), all of my test data are classified, but the performance of the model suffers.
Is there any other filtering level that can be used, or is 1 standard error from the minimum fairly standard for this type of modeling?

Ah right, the feature selection from regularization! This is what regularization does for you -- finds the features (words in this case) in your data that are predictive of your categories. It sounds like you have a lot of observations that are harder to predict.

You might try plain old logistic regression, instead of glmnet, and see how you do. This will not do any regularization and you can see how your model performs if you keep all the words. Also, you can read up on glmnet itself and see what your options are for dialing down the regularization, although like you found, your model will not perform as well.

Great Post as usual! I have some confusions.
Do we get the similar results as using tf_idf method? Do you think its superior to old log-odd ratio method and if not when should we choose one from two?

The benefit of the weighted log odds ratio over the regular version of log odds ratio is that it tries to account for sampling variability, i.e. the fact that sometimes you have counted different features a very different number of times. If the counts are about the same for all features, then it won't make much difference, but if you have big differences in your counts (some things have been counted a lot and some have been counted a few times, like we often find with words in a document, or with names) then the weighting helps.

We talk a bit about log odds comparing to tf-df in the vignette for tidylo here:
https://github.com/juliasil...
And Tyler talks about it in more detail in his post that I linked to. They are not actually similar (tf-idf is a heuristic quantity, and odds ratios are a different way to state probabilities) but they can both be used to identify features that are specific to one item within a set.

An hypothesis to explain the gender:experience interaction, based on my own (anecdotal) experience. The time comes for a new buzzworthy technology to be tried out at a workplace. The aggressively competitive male shoves his way into that position, in part by spending many hours outside of work to read up on Kubernetes or whatever that technology is. He continues to do this over his career, accumulating experience with a variety of valuable buzzwords, such that his years are valued very highly by the market.

His female coworker is less aggressive, and especially if she has kids, less willing to spend four hours a night putting time in on the new buzzword, because she has other priorities. Thus, while she is getting more years of experience, they are more often in the "old" stuff, which is less highly valued by the market.

Just an hypothesis, but it would explain the interaction seen, and also accords with my own anecdotal experience.

Thanks again!

This is great feedback, and aligns with some other thoughts we've been having about these functions. 🙌

The {tune} package, where `fit_resamples()` comes from, has a couple of different functions that fit models to resamples.

The `fit_resamples()` function does not perform any tuning of the model and is used just for computing a set of performance metrics: https://tidymodels.github.i...
If we want to actually find a better model using the resamples, we need to use one of the `tune_` functions, such as `tune_grid()`:
https://tidymodels.github.i...

We'll be sharing more about these modeling tasks soon!

But isn't the model being fitted a different one than the one you fit without vfold? The variables are identical and so are the hyper paramaters, but the model is fit on a different subset(s) of the data, so the model itself is different.

i.e. if it was a linear regression model, it was y = 0.2 + 0.5x when it was fitted on the entire train set, and now it's y = 0.15 + 0.37x when fitted using vfold. No?

Yes, that's right; it sounds like you understand what `fit_resamples()` is doing. The output of that function does not include the models themselves; it throws away the models because the point of that function is only to estimate performance metrics such as RMSE across a set of resamples.

So first fit on 9 folds and evaluate on 1, then fit on a different set of 9 folds and evaluate on another, etc. Then use how all those 10 models performed on their evaluation sets to estimate how the original model will perform. The data I used in the video demonstrates pretty nicely how this gives a more accurate estimate of performance than only using the training set once.

However, when I try to do the fit_resamples() I get an error stating that Fold01: formula: Error in contrasts<-(*tmp*, value = contr.funs[1 + isOF[nn]]): contrasts can be applied only to factors with 2 or more…, even though 1) there is no factors at all, 2) it's the same data used (just split using vfolds_cv()) used before, with the same model as before.

Any idea what I might be doing wrong? :) Or could it be a bug?

I am not entirely sure based on just this, but it's possible that the model is trying to fit or predict for a categorical variable when there was only one level (value) that ended up in a CV split? If you can put together a reproducible example showing the code you used, perhaps in a gist, we could figure out what has happened.

Thank you for replying! Almost uncanny that I sat and made a github-markdown the exact moment your reply hit my mailbox! https://github.com/drmuu/R4...

I've been talking with the R4DS Slack-group aswell, and they helped me figure out that the problem atleast is with the categorical variables, since it works if I drop every other variable except price and points.

The issue here is that a lot of these columns (like winery, title, etc) have many, many unique values. During cross validation, when it's time to train the model on the analysis part of the split and evaluate on the assessment part of the split, there aren't the same sets of winery names and wine titles, etc, in both sections. This means that the model breaks; it learned what to do with a certain set of titles/wineries/etc but not the ones that are in the assessment part of the split.

You can get around this by fitting to a *recipe* instead of a formula, and add a step to your recipe that is especially built to deal with new levels in factor/nominal data:
wine_rec <- recipe(points ~ ., data = wine_train) %>%
step_novel(all_nominal())
Use that instead of the formula in `fit_resamples()`.

Hi Julia, really enjoying the tidymodels blog posts and videos - very interesting!

Let me see if I can answer some of these!

`set_mode()` is used to change a model's mode so no, no difference from doing it as an argument in the main model function:
https://tidymodels.github.i...

`step_normalize()` is just more concise: https://tidymodels.github.i...

I don't think there is a real reason to bake() the test data either when I did or at the end; the reason I did it where I did was to show what bake() is doing. Data leakage could occur if you accidentally use the test data in training, I suppose.

If you check out the documentation for `step_downsample()` you'll see what happens with bake() and juice() and how you actually get the downsampled data:
https://tidymodels.github.i...

If you want only accuracy out of `collect_metrics()` you can use `filter()` to get that. If you only want to calculate accuracy during the resampling, check out the `metrics` argument: https://tidymodels.github.i...

If you have more involved questions on any of this, it might be easier to ask on https://community.rstudio.com/, where there is better support for including code, output, etc. If you @-mention me, I will see it! 👍
Thank you @dorothea78:disqus ! Will direct future code-related questions on community.rstudio.com :)

Ah, in this video I was using the current GitHub version of tune, in which we made an adjustment based on user feedback to what you actually "fit". Install like this:
`devtools::install_github("tidymodels/tune")`
And then try again!

Hmmm, I'm not sure why you wouldn't want to prep the recipe or use a formula in fit_resamples(); you can indeed use it in the way I have shown. I can see why you are finding tidymodels confusing as it's a really fully featured way to approach modeling and that can be overwhelming. That's part of what I'm trying to help with here!

On your last question, YES, absolutely. This is a common use case for topic modeling. You can either do this somewhat manually using the output you get from stm, or you can check out how this is implemented in the textrecipes package, using step_lda():
https://github.com/tidymode...
There are not hard and fast rules about what the "right" number of topics is so it can be tough to decide. Given what you said here about residuals and held-out likelihood and the characteristics of the topics, I think I would lean toward 8 topics (semantic coherence always goes down with more topics).

I think Abderrahim has a point. Your code writes
"vfold_cv(uni_juiced, strata = diversity)". So, you use the already juiced data in the cross-validation. Isn't this a data leakage? Shouldn't you do the preprocessing separately for each cross-validation iteration? Otherwise, you calculate preprocessing parameters (such as mean or std dev. in normalization) using the entire training data. So validation sample in each cross-validation iteration is also used for pre-processing. Hence the data leakage.
What do you think?

"Error in margin(b = strip_text_margin) : unused argument (b = strip_text_margin)"

No worries. Figured it out. Namespace got changed because I loaded another package with the same `margin` function. Thanks.
If you followed exactly this code, then the object with the final fit is final_res. You can check out last_fit to see more details on it. It contains the fitted model which you can pass new data to.

Yes, topic modeling gives you probabilities, not counts. If you wanted to only look at words with some kind of emotional valence, I might try an inner_join() with a sentiment lexicon before the modeling, i.e. only model words that have some kind of sentiment label. Sometimes people will only model nouns or nouns + verbs, and that is somewhat similar in spirit.

Another option would be to inner_join() with a sentiment lexicon after the modeling and then to weight by probability instead of count? Those would be some ideas to try out.

Ah OK! I have seen this problem intermittently too and I thought this was the problem. I just pushed a change to the package where it now calls ggplot2::margin instead which should fix this. You can reinstall and it shouldn't do this anymore.

Thanks for the response. It seems like that function is used like you did, to evaluate a final model with a required split object. But what if I want to use it to predict without a split object? Is there a predict function somewhere in there?

I'm getting mixed up between having multiple recipes, workflows, juicing, prepping, baking, etc and then what types of objects are passing between all of those portions of the modeling process.
I think I answered my own question, predict is a function in parsnip. So it would be predict(final_res, new_data)
Yes the updated version works perfectly. thanks!
You wouldn't fit on the whole final_res object, but instead on the object in the .workflow column. Check out the pull_workflow_fit() function.

Got it! So new_data is run on the tree_rec recipe, which is then prepped and juiced. Then predict.model_fit is run on the object that comes from pull_workflow_fit(final_res$.workflow[[1]]). I get an error when just using $.workflow. Otherwise that works for me and then I can use bind_cols to add to the new_data.

Hi,
Under this final step, fit(legal_status ~ ., data = juice(tree_prep), is it not best to pass tree_train instead of juiced one?

For the variable importance calculation, if you send tree_train instead of the preprocessed data, you will not get the variable importance of individual levels (i.e. the indicator or dummy variables) within the factors like "private caretaker" and instead will only get the variable importance of "caretaker".

One little correction that i found when working through your code (i tried the cumsum alternative). The ggplot aes parameter should be 'percent_var' not 'percent_variation'.


tibble(
component = unique(tidied_pca$component),
percent_var = percent_variation ## use cumsum() to find cumulative, if you prefer
) %>%
mutate(component = fct_inorder(component)) %>%
ggplot(aes(component, percent_var)) +
geom_col() +
scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
labs(x = NULL, y = "Percent variance explained by each PCA component")

Yep, these functions use prcomp() under the hood, as you can see here. What tidymodels offers is a consistent, expressive way to implement modeling, not typically new implementations of any models.

You could certainly make the heldout datasets earlier, since it only depends on hacker_news_sparse. It is more like creating resampled datasets than a simple train/test split but the same general idea.

This is awesome and worked for me! Grid tuning was nearly 4x faster after I added this:

all_cores <- parallel::detectCores(logical = FALSE)
library(doParallel)
cl <- makePSOCKcluster(all_cores)
registerDoParallel(cl)

Taken from tune's documentation

This is an excellent course - thanks so much for putting this together.

In chapter 3 you use the last_fit function to fit the entire training set and then evaluate on the test set. The final selected workflow includes a recipe with an upsampling step. Does this mean that using last_fit results in the test data being upsampled before predictions (and performance metrics) are calculated?

When using the final selected model on completely new data (that wasn't in training or test) is there a way to apply the same transformations as determined during original model fitting e.g. imputing missing values using the mean observed in the original training dataset and then to calculate predictions from the final selected model (without applying any upsampling to this new data)?

You can check out the code for last_fit() for yourself if you like, but NO, the test data is not upsampled. Upsampling should only be performed on training data and testing metrics should be calculated on data as you find it in the wild.

What you describe in the second paragraph is how recipes is built to work. Data preprocessing steps and transformations are estimated from the training data but then applied to new data.

I think this issue occurs because your version of tidyr is old. You have to pass a named list instead of just the value 0 so you can do

pivot_wider(names_from = ingredient, values_from = measure_number, values_fill = list(measure_number = 0))

I have a question about cross validation as it applies to data with a longitudinal structure: in this example with NFL attendance, just say we are predicting a datapoint in the `test` set, eg. attendance numbers for an NFL game in, say, 2015.

The model would then be trained on data that includes attendance numbers for many NFL games from 2016, 2017, 2018, etc--i.e. data that did not yet exist in 2015.

If I were trying to think of how to give meaningful measures of predictive ability of a model from first principles, I would have thought we’d want to train the model on rolling windows of data--i.e. to predict 2015 datapoints, the `train` set would only contain data pre-2015; then for predicting 2016 datapoints, `train` would contain pre-2106 data.

Am I on the right track? Are there statistical models or R packages that I should read-up more on to do this? I know we can assess timeseries predictions (eg. model one particular team's attendance over time as one timeseries), but the data in this NFL game seems to be better modelled as longitudinal (to take advantage of the fact that we have timeseries data for many teams). I wonder if there are any tips on how to perform cross validation in this longitudinal context?

Thank you,
Jeremy

When you tidy the prepped recipe, be sure to access the right step "number". Here I use 2, because the PCA step is step number 2. It's probably another number for you if you added a step_mutate() and/or other steps.

Another very interesting dataset, thanks. I am surprised you aggregated mission years into decades for your boxplots. A scatterplot of log(hours_mission) against year is more informative.

The dataset includes both the Challenger and Columbia disasters. The first would be excluded by taking logs and then keeping only positive values (although your code suggests you did this in the reverse order). The second should probably be excluded as well. There are minor flaws in the Challenger data (e.g., four astronauts get a different coding and mission time to the other three).

Have I understood you correctly that you treat astronauts on the same mission (who should all have the same mission time) as independent cases in your modelling?

Yes, there are a couple of options with this dataset: look at per-mission information, look at per-astronaut information, or look at per-mission-per-astronaut information. In the end, year and spacecraft were more important than predictors like occupation or civilian/military status so it's possible that a cleaner approach would have been to only look at per-mission information.

Precision is classification metric, with a definition here that depends on having a hard class prediction.

It sounds like you may be more interested in a class probability metric, like one of these.

hello Julia,

In tidymodels, how to set positive value on outcome variable?
For example, if I have the variable diabetes. Its levels is 1 or 2, how to set the positive one?
think you vary much.

There was a change in the yardstick package recently in how event levels are handled, where a global option was switched out for an explicit argument. This changed how the base or first event level was inferred in this case. To get your plot to work correctly, you need to either switch out predicted probability you use:

roc_curve(win, .pred_lose)

Or specify it's the second level that is the "event":

roc_curve(win, .pred_win, event_level = "second")
Thank you! your answer help me.

Hi Julia, just a question regarding bootstraps and the last_fit function.

When using bootstraps(), we can use the strata argument to balance a dataset with unequal amounts of our target variable.
This makes as many "splits" as we require, which we can then use with tune_grid(), to work out the best model hyper-parameters.

ie, the tune_grid function runs the all the recipe steps on each of the analysis splits, trains a model and then uses that model to predict on the assessment part of the split.

But when we use last_fit() on the full training data (which hasn't been bootstrapped), won't our last model be worse because it hasn't been stratified (is this the right word?)... when making predictions on our test dataset?

Would it be normal to use a step_bootstrap in the recipe instead of in the pre-tune_grid splitting section (and use vfold_cv instead of bootstraps when making our splits)?

I've seen step_upsample and step_downsample but no step_bootstrap. Would there be any difference between these?

Cheers,
Julian

When you are doing the initial_split() to create the training and testing sets, you can also set a strata argument to make sure that even the training and testing sets are balanced in, say, the outcome. This can be important if you have a quite imbalanced dataset, and then the datasets going into last_fit() are also balanced.

A bootstrap is a resampling operation (make lots of new datasets) while upsampling or downsampling is an operation that makes or takes away observations in one dataset.

Thanks for this. I'm still trying to get my head around it. Let's see if I understand...

I think I get that initial_split() isn't removing or duplicating any rows, it's just making sure that there is roughly the same proportion of the levels of the selected column in the training and testing sets.

But using bootstraps to generate many different splits for the tune_grid's resamples does. It duplicates the rows of less frequent levels of the selected column in the analysis sets (but not the assessment sets).

Say I tried tune_grid() over 20 different model configs. If I then select_best(), then finalize_workflow() and then run last_fit() with the finalized_workflow and the initial_split() data object...

And that the resulting model will be inferior to the example that got created back in the tune_grid step?

What's the best way for me to tell last_fit() to apply bootstrapping to the training data?

Hope I'm making sense, here.

ps, I have a (perhaps overly) complicated github repo that I'm using drake with, if you were curious (could make a great next video for your youtube series).
https://github.com/Tadge-Analytics/airbnb-kaggle-comp

Cheers
Julian

Ah, I think you may be misunderstanding what bootstraps() does. It does not add or remove rows; it does the same stratified sampling (but sampling with replacement to get to the same size) that initial_split() does.

You can add or remove rows to get a balanced dataset using step_upsample() or step_downsample().

Check out this gist where I demonstrate:
https://gist.github.com/jul...

I am fitting a very simple penalized regression on diamonds data set, but it just came back with errors. How do you usually debug your models when things go wrong?

Code below:
```
library(tidymodels)
diamonds_df <- ggplot2::diamonds

preprocess <- recipe(price~., data = diamonds_df)

diamond_baked <- juice(preprocess %>% prep)

diamonds_cv2 <- vfold_cv(diamond_baked, v = 5)

glmnet_model <- linear_reg(
mode = "regression",
penalty = tune(),
mixture = tune()
) %>%
set_engine("glmnet")

glmnet_wfl <- workflow() %>%
add_recipe(preprocess) %>%
add_model(glmnet_model)

glmnet_params <- parameters(penalty(), mixture())

glmnet_grid <- grid_max_entropy(glmnet_params, size = 20)

glmnet_cv_result <- tune_grid(
glmnet_wfl,
resamples = diamonds_cv2,
grid = glmnet_grid,
metrics = metric_set(mae, mape, rmse, rsq),
control = control_grid(verbose = TRUE)
)
#> i Fold1: recipe
#> v Fold1: recipe
#> i Fold1: model 1/20
#> x Fold1: model 1/20: Error in elnet(x, is.sparse, ix, jx, y, weights, offset, ty...
#> i Fold1: model 2/20
#> x Fold1: model 2/20: Error in elnet(x, is.sparse, ix, jx, y, weights, offset, ty...
#> Warning: All models failed in tune_grid(). See the `.notes` column.```
<sup>Created on 2020-08-10 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v0.3.0)</sup>```

Ingesting data is definitely a whole other thing and can be a real challenge. If the data is in PDF form, I like to use pdftools and do something like this:
https://stackoverflow.com/q...
If they are in some other file format, often the readr package has a good way to ingest it. Identifying who is speaking in a transcript depends very much on the particular way your text is encoded and set up, but generally you would want to use a regex and set up a new column similar to the chapter column here:
https://www.tidytextmining....

Glad to hear. Me too.

I suspect that the packages have to explicitly defined for the workers (and it is not related to compatibility between prep function and step_textfeature).

The following solution works for me on a windows 10 machine (having the latest packages from CRAN):


# doParallel::registerDoParallel()
# https://tune.tidymodels.org/articles/extras/optimizations.html

all_cores <- parallel::detectCores(logical = FALSE)

cl <- parallel::makePSOCKcluster(all_cores)
doParallel::registerDoParallel(cl)
foreach::getDoParName()
foreach::getDoParWorkers()

parallel::clusterEvalQ(cl, {library(tidymodels)})
parallel::clusterEvalQ(cl, {library(textrecipes)})

https://tune.tidymodels.org...

Hmmmm, typically if you get AUC below 0.5, that may be a sign that you have a mistake in how you labeled your outcomes, i.e. they are reversed. Since I published this blog post, there was a change in yardstick for how the event of interest is denoted.

The other thing to be aware of is that you want to see about the same AUC for the training and testing sets; when you see different values, that is a sign that something has gone wrong, probably overfitting to the training set.
