Wow ok, this tidymodel framework is a bit of a brain-twister!

I think the bit that's throwing me is the workflows package and what is actually being 'produced' at the very end. How does one extract the final model trained on the full dataset once the set of parameters have been found so it can be saved for future use? The collect_predictions extracts the predictions for the test set, but what if I wanted the full dataset? Also it's not clear the model has been trained on the full dataset with the optimised parameters or if its done on the training dataset only? Is the recipe prepared on the full dataset or is still only prepped on the initial training split? I have so many questions

You can check out some of the details of the last_fit() function here:
https://tune.tidymodels.org...
It's a convenience function to fit on the training set and evaluate on the test set.

You could save that object for future use, or you could do something like:
final_xgb %>% fit(data = vb_train) %>% pull_workflow_fit()
and save that for future use, if that is better/clearer for you.

One of the benefits of using a workflow() is that it handles the correct preprocessing for you. The recipe is prepared on the training set only, and then applied to test sets or other analysis sets in the case of tuning. The design of the workflows package is set up to protect against data leakage during preprocessing.

Hi Julia,
First of all, you are a wizard. All of your content has been amazingly helpful with my modelling for my university thesis. Particularly the screencasts from Tidy Tuesday!

I have looked through your examples to try to combine cross validation ('vfold_cv'), roles ('update_role') and hyperparameter tuning, however I couldn't find anything that addresses them. Would you know how to use all three together?

I will use diamonds as an example - Thanks again for all your wonderful resources!
```{r}

library(tidymodels)
library(ids)
diamonds <- ggplot2::diamonds
diamonds <- sample_n(diamonds, 1000)
diamonds$ln_price <- log10(diamonds$price)
diamonds_sub <- diamonds %>%
select(-price) %>%
mutate(cut = as.factor(cut)) %>%
mutate(color = as.factor(color)) %>%
mutate(clarity = as.factor(clarity)) %>%
mutate(unique_id = ids::random_id(n = nrow(diamonds), bytes = 4))

set.seed(12345)
split <- initial_split(diamonds_sub, prop = 0.7) #Sampling
train_data <- training(split)
test_data <- testing(split)

diamond_recipe <- recipe(ln_price ~., data = train_data) %>%
update_role(unique_id, new_role = "unique_id") %>%
step_corr(all_numeric()) %>%
step_dummy(all_nominal(), -all_outcomes()) %>%
step_zv(all_numeric(), -all_outcomes()) %>%
step_normalize(all_numeric(), -all_outcomes())

diamonds_prep <- prep(diamond_recipe, strings_as_factors = F)
train_prepped <- diamonds_prep %>% bake(new_data = train_data)
test_prepped <- diamonds_prep %>% bake(new_data = test_data)

diamond_folds <- vfold_cv(train_data, v = 5)
diamond_folds_sub <- vfold_cv(train_data[,-11], v = 5)
diamond_folds_prepped <- vfold_cv(train_prepped, v = 5)

#Lasso Model as Example
lasso_spec <- linear_reg(penalty = tune(), mixture = 1) %>% set_mode("regression") %>% set_engine("glmnet")
lasso_wf <- workflow() %>% add_recipe(diamond_recipe) %>% add_model(lasso_spec)
lasso_params <- parameters(lasso_wf)

#Trying Different Ways to exclude "unique_id" from the validation
lasso_tuned <- lasso_wf %>% tune_bayes(resamples = diamond_folds,param_info = lasso_params, iter = 3, metrics = metric_set(rmse))
lasso_tuned_sub <- lasso_wf %>% tune_bayes(resamples = diamond_folds_sub,param_info = lasso_params, iter = 3, metrics = metric_set(rmse))
lasso_tuned_prepped <- lasso_wf %>% tune_bayes(resamples = diamond_folds_prepped,param_info = lasso_params, iter = 3, metrics = metric_set(rmse))
It's a little hard to go back and forth with this much code in blog comments. Can you post on RStudio Community? It's better suited for this kind of thing: https://rstd.io/tidymodels-...

The findThoughts() function returns the top documents ranked by the topic's document-topic probabilities, so that's the same as this dataframe:

We really need to get those new versions out; I am sorry for the installation troubles you are having!

My approach when I have trouble like this is to try to update other things first (i.e. update.packages() and get everything on CRAN updated) and then do the GitHub installation again. I would recommend restarting R before starting this process.

With lambda_grid <- grid_regular(penalty(), levels = 50), we get a grid of lambda values, which we can view in a histogram: lambda_grid %>% ggplot(aes(penalty)) + geom_histogram(). Running this shows the possible lambda values are skewed to 0. Why should we expect lambda to be closer to 0? I don't understand what penalty() is doing here.

Typically with regularized models, we try out values of for the regularization penalty chosen on a logarithmic scale, with lots of values spaced close together closer to zero and fewer values spaced further apart further away from zero. This is because when the regularization penalty is really small, small changes in it can have a big effect. You can see a nice walk through of a regularized model in this example:
https://www.tidymodels.org/...

Hi! Thank you very much for the great tutorial. I have a question. How can I use the output of "fit_resamples" to predict the test data? I understand that we tried to solve the over-fitting problem on the training set by cross-validation, but how can I extract the model comes from "fit_resamples"? How can I use it on the test set?
Thank you.

There are no fitted models that come out of `fit_resamples()` to be used for predictions; the models created during the resampling process (fit on little mini subsamples of the data) are trained for the purpose of evaluating performance. If some particular modeling approach does turn out to be the best option, then the best choice is to fit again to the whole training set so the model parameters can be estimate with more data. You can check out this chapter to learn more about using resampling:

https://www.tmwr.org/resamp...

Hi Julia,

The recipe package has functions like step_mutate() and step_naomit() for preprocessing. However, I see that you preprocess the data yourself. Are there any pros/cons of using the above two functions?

Thanks,

Yes, the most important thing to think about is how the step will behave when applied to new data. Take a look at this section:
https://www.tmwr.org/recipe...
I generally recommend using recipes functions for transformations you want to learn from training data and apply to new data, and using other tidyverse functions for simpler, deterministic transformations.

Hi Julia,
Something that I have found is that quite some poeple had the problem with the fit resamples function, some attributed it to tune not being install, or some conflict.
knn_res <- tune::fit_resamples(
+ children ~ .,
+ knn_spec,
+ validation_splits,
+ control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE)
+ )
Error: The first argument to [fit_resamples()] should be either a model or workflow.
Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.

I bangged my head against the wall for a few hours, luckily I use RStudio Cloud to learn and as a test environment, and found that is very powerful in interpreting the code and making suggestions as to what would be the right thing to do. So I put the whole script on RSCloud and promted the following message.

Warning message:
`fit_resamples.formula()` is deprecated as of lifecycle 0.1.0.
The first argument to `fit_resamples()` should be either a model or a workflow. In the future, you can use:
fit_resamples(knn_spec, children ~ ., resamples = validation_splits,
control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))

And so pasted that code and worked perfectly in the cloud, changed it in my local R Studio installation and also worked, if someone is having the same problem I highly encourage you to use this

fit_resamples(knn_spec, children ~ ., resamples = validation_splits,
+ control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))

The output is the same I've seen and it changes the order of children to knn_spec and adds a resamples=.

If you find this usefull let me know!

This data is based on the attached paper **Hotel booking demand datasets**. It consists of two datasets with real hotel demand data from Portugal. One of the hotels (H1) is a resort hotel and the other is a city hotel (H2). Both datasets share the same structure, with 31 variables describing the 40,060 observations of H1 and 79,330 observations of H2.
1. which type of hotels has more cancellations? `hotel1_reservation_status.png`
1. What is the relationship between `lead_time` and whether a booking was cancelled or not?
1. What proportions of sales happenin each channel? Again you need to group your anaysis ny type of hotel and examine distribution (relevant variable = `market_segment`)
1. What is the deposit policy (`deposit_type`)? Do we ask for deposits in some segments more than others?
1. For those customers who did stay, how many (number and %) travelled with kids?
1. How do actual hotel stays of guests with/without children vary throughout the year? Is this different in the city and the resort hotel? `hotel2_proportion_stayed_by_month.png`
1. Are hotel guests with children more likely to require a parking space? `hotel3_parking_children.png`
1. Do people with children spend more? What is the average spend? Is the difference statistically significant?
1. There is various `meal` plans:
- BB: Bed and Breakfast
- HB: Half Board
- FB: Full Board

Hello Julia,

Thanks again for the great screencast. Your screencasts are one of the best ML I've ever had chance to learn. I ran to the following error. I rechecked all my codes and couldn't figure out what is going on. I really appreciate if you help me out.
Error: The first argument to [fit_resamples()] should be either a model or workflow. Run `rlang::last_error()` to see where the error occurred.
5.
stop(fallback)
4.
signal_abort(cnd)
3.
rlang::abort(msg)
2.
fit_resamples.default(weekly_attendance ~ ., rf_spec, nlf_folds, control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))
1.
fit_resamples(weekly_attendance ~ ., rf_spec, nlf_folds, control = control_resamples(save_pred = TRUE))

There have been some changes to a few packages since I published this post, so what you need to do is follow the instructions in the error message: "The first argument to [fit_resamples()] should be either a model or workflow." Switch the order of the first two argument you have to fit_resamples() so that the model rf_spec comes first.

Thank you very much. I really appreciate all the great screen-casts. I am going through all of them. So far, this is the third one. Incidentally, I ran to the same problem. I changed some of the orders and so far the model worked.
And, It worked for the predictive modeling as well. Thank you very much.

Hi Julia,

Thanks so much for this. Really helpful. I'm afraid I'm having a few problems with the code. For context, I'm a moderately experienced R user, am comfortable with Tidyverse, but by no means an expert.

Two difficulties I'm having:

The first is pretty simple, and was easy to solve. When I run:

library(tidytext)

tidy_hacker_news <- hacker_news_text %>%
unnest_tokens(word, text, token = "tweets") %>%
anti_join(get_stopwords()) %>%
filter(!str_detect(word, "[0-9]+")) %>%
add_count(word) %>%
filter(n > 100) %>%
select(-n)

I get the following error:

Error in out[!(index_twitter | index_url)] <- stri_trans_tolower(out[!(index_twitter | :
NAs are not allowed in subscripted assignments

I solve that easily enough by changing the code to:

hacker_news_text <- hacker_news_text %>%
drop_na()

missing <- hacker_news_text %>%
select_if(function(x) any(is.na(x))) %>%
summarise_each(funs(sum(is.na(.))))

That seems to do the trick, but just wanted to let you know in case it's something others are experiencing.

The bigger problem is with this chunk of code:

many_models<- many_models %>%
mutate(topic_model = future_map(K, ~stm(hacker_news_sparse, K = 10,
verbose = TRUE)))

I know it's expected to take a while, but I've left it running for over 48 hours, and it's still processing. I'm running a mac mini i3 with OS 10.15.7, so everything should be up to date and able to handle the task.

I should note I get a warning that plan(multiprocess) is deprecated and is now multicore, and multicore won't allow parallel processing in Rstudio. Even when I try in base R, though, I still have the same problem.

Any thoughts on what I can do here? Mastering this will be really helpful for a project I'm working on.

Thanks for your help!

WOW, that does not sound right! I am wondering why you have an object called many_models and then you are trying to map over it. If you have K = 10, then there isn't any reason to use map and parallel processing, because the models will all turn out the same.

You're right. That was a change I made to see if I can get the command with only one value of K instead of the entire vector. I left it in by mistake when posting.

For whatever it's worth, I modified the command to:

many_models %>%
mutate(topic_model = stm(hacker_news_sparse, K = 20, verbose = T))

This allows me to test only one value of K, and by setting verbose to TRUE, I can get a sense of what's happening behind the scenes. It looks like it works fine, until it comes time mutate( ) and add the new column.

When I try your original code:

many_models <- data_frame(K = c(20, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 100)) %>%
mutate(topic_model = future_map(K, ~stm(hacker_news_sparse, K = .,
verbose = FALSE)))

or when I try to modify it like I posted above:

many_models<- many_models %>%
mutate(topic_model = future_map(K, ~stm(hacker_news_sparse, K = 10,
verbose = TRUE)))

The same thing happens: it processes indefinitely. Notice that I set verbose to TRUE in my modified code, in the hopes I could get some sense of where the problem was. Nothing is displayed, so I'm not sure the stm( ) function even starts to run. It looks like maybe it's being held up indefinitely at the future_map ( ) function.

Apologies for the mistake in the original post. Thanks again for any help you're able to offer.

If you are using parallel processing, then typically logging just goes out the window, unfortunately. The parallel workers just eat up the logging and the verbose doesn't do anything.

Can you try fitting the model one time without parallel processing and just one value for K? To see how long it takes? How much data do you have? Still 100,000 rows as shown in this post?

tictoc gave an elapsed time of 580 seconds, so slightly under 10 minutes. Since there were seven values of K in many_models, it seems like the model with all the K values should take slightly over an hour, assuming all K values take the same time.

And I got a time back of 35.5 seconds, so a little longer.

Ah, gotcha. 👍 For a corpus of that size, you probably want to try models between 3-30 topics or so.

If you don't want to use parallel processing, you can switch out `future_map()` for `map()`. If you want to create a dataframe to store the different models, I do think you will need to use `map()`.

Hi Julia,
In the tidied_pca graph, how could I change the bars color based on tidied_pca$component (component, TAG) that instead contains color names (I'm doing PCA for colors) I can get it to work with a palette since I have more than 200+colors.....any tips :-)

https://stackoverflow.com/q...

It was as simple as to add one line of code = + scale_fill_identity()

tidied_pca %>%
filter(PC == "PC2") %>%
top_n(40, abs(Contribution)) %>%
mutate(Tag = reorder(Tag, Contribution)) %>%
ggplot(aes(Tag, Contribution, fill=Tag)) + scale_fill_identity() +
geom_col(show.legend = FALSE, alpha = 0.8) +
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5),
axis.ticks.x = element_blank()) +
labs(x = "Bottle Color percentages",
y = "Relative importance in principle component",
title = "What color accounts for most variation PCA2")

Great video, but I ran into a glitch I could not figure out. The update_role didn't assign the new_role= "ID". Then step_dummy was applied to the ID var. So, I just dropped the ID var. Has anyone had this issue:

tree_rec <- recipe(dv ~ ., data = trees_train) %>%
update_role(guid, new_role = "ID") %>%
#step_rm(guid) %>%
step_dummy(all_nominal(), -all_outcomes()) %>%
step_date(date, features = c("year")) %>%
step_rm(date) %>%
step_downsample(dv)

Ah, this does trip folks up sometimes. The identifier all_nominal select all nominal variables, like it indicates in the name, not all nominal predictors. This includes non-predictor variables, including outcomes, anything that has been "updated" like your ID variable, etc. You could either say step_dummy(all_nominal(), -all_outcomes(), -guid) or you could deselect it with the selector function has_role().

There is definitely support for precision, recall, and F measure in yardstick:
https://yardstick.tidymodel...
https://yardstick.tidymodel...
https://yardstick.tidymodel...

We have a full tutorial in the works for working with thresholds and ROC curves so look out for that.

In the meantime, before we get a more thorough tutorial set up, check out this function:
https://probably.tidymodels...

This is a good illustration of the problem of throwing data around without seeking to understand the underlying meaning. Your most important variable is the type of crash report, whether police completed the report on scene or not. If drivers can leave the scene prior to reporting the crash it implies that the crash was less severe. The main thing your model "predicts" is whether or not drivers who are injured or who have injured passengers will leave the scene of a crash prior to calling the police, or whether police will decide they need to come to the scene of such a crash. If this is what you're trying to predict, that's fine, but the implication is that the model can help determine the types of crashes which are more likely to cause injury, which it cannot.
Well, no surprise that I disagree with your assessment of my work! 😉 I discuss that issue of the reporting in the video, and how it is predictive but not causal.

first and foremost - have to echo everyone and say your videos/blogs are great!

Two quick questions -
1) I got confused in your video when you used kfold with a bagged model - don't all bagged models use/need bagged resamples? Can you speak on bagging vs kfold resampling when using non-ensemble and ensemble learners?
2) How do you handle the time component aspect of this dataset? This is a predictive model so I get the deemphasis on inference (autocorrelation and spatial autocorrelation for that matter) and classical timeseries considerations but you didn't perform timeseries specific resampling - I guess that's because you're not predicating say something like "accidents resulting injuries per day".

Thanks in advance!

Yes! I like partykit (with maybe ggparty) for that a lot, but you will probably need to use repair_call(), like this:
https://www.tidyverse.org/b...

I will say that I was confused about resampling vs. bagging when I started learning about all this too, because they seem like similar ideas. One thing that helped me keep straight in my head what is going on is how extremely similar bagged trees are to random forest models. It seems really normal to me to use something like cross-validation when training a random forest model; we would use cross-validation for a bagged tree model for the same reasons, to answer the same kinds of questions.

As far as the date/time features here, this isn't time series in the sense that I want to predict the next crash(es). Instead it is a classification model where some of the predictors happen to be date features. You can look at another example of this kind of model here: https://www.tidymodels.org/...

hmmmmmm am I mistaking bootstrap and kfold resampling as alternatives to each other? It seems that kfold is used to tune hyperparameters and bootstrap resampling is used to take poor learners and "make them better" by aggregating their performance - as in they preform different tasks/not-interchangeable.

The bootstrap and cross-validation are both resampling approaches, and model practitioners might be most used to "doing it themselves" for the purpose of evaluating model performance or tuning hyperparameters, like explained here:
https://www.tmwr.org/resamp...
In this context, you could use either one (definitely alternatives to each other) and might want to consider how much data you have to make a choice.

Bagging is a portmanteau of "bootstrap aggregating" and random forests work very similarly (but pick features differently for splitting nodes) and here the resampling is done with a different purpose: averaging model predictions.

Hi Julia, great tutorial - thanks a lot! I have the issue that my classifications are not really doing well because of imbalanced data. Is there a way I can account for this fact in the code you've provided? Can't seem to get my head around it. Thanks for your help!

I would recommend to use downsampling or even a combination of downsampling and upsampling.

In your recipe add the 2 steps:
themis::step_downsample(target_variable, under_ratio = 2) %>%
themis::step_smote(target_variable)

Imagine you have a set with yes (n=100) and no (n=900). So we have only 10% of yes (or a 1:9 ratio).
When you perform step_downsample, we will randomly throw away 800 no-cases, to make the data even (ratio = 1:1). Now the "problem" with only undersampling data is, that we loose a lot of data, right.
Therefore I included the upsampling step using the SMOTE algorithm.
But first let's look at the "under_ratio = 2" parameter. This will "only" throw away 700 no-cases, so we end up with a 1:2 ratio (100-yes : 200-no). When we upsample with SMOTE, we generate synthetic samples from the minority class (yes) using knn. We will end up with a 1:1 ratio (or 200-yes : 200-no).
This may solve your class imbalance but reduce the loss of model performance power you would have from step_downsample alone.

Now, you should try out different values for the "under_ratio" parameter (use tune() here!) and compare the model metrics.

I hope I was of any help. Here is some literature that I found helpful:

Chawla, N. V., Bowyer, K. W., Hall, L. O., & Kegelmeyer, W. P. (2002). SMOTE: Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique. Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research, 16, 321–357. https://doi.org/10.1613/jai...
T. Ryan Hoens, & Nitesh V. Chawla (2013). Imbalanced Datasets: From Sampling to Classifiers. In Imbalanced Learning (pp. 43–59). John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. https://doi.org/10.1002/978...
S. Liu, M. L. Ong, K. Kin Mun, J. Yao, & M. Motani (2019). Early Prediction of Sepsis via SMOTE Upsampling and Mutual Information Based Downsampling. In 2019 Computing in Cardiology (CinC).
